Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, a moment of your time, please?
Certainly... Any particular reason you're caressing that dagger of yours?
I'm in a martial mood. This helps me sharpen my thinking.
I see. So long as it remains sheathed, we're fine. Now, about this moment– you have my complete attention.
Thank you. As you know, my original plans called for me to have six 38s installed.
A fact which hasn't diminished our effectiveness.
Not in your eyes.
Nor that of the Kriegsmarine, I'd bet.
I'm not complaining, Kapitän, only stating facts. The fact is that I was supposed to be more heavily armed than I am. I wish to rectify that.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. I'd like you to get right on that.
You're right. If you can spare the time, I'd like you to work on this.
I'll leave that up to you, Gneisenau. I don't have the time for it right now.

Fields.DialogueText: So you're saying I'm on my own?
Spare the time? Isn't this important to you too?
As Kapitän, isn't your time as free as you make it?
My answer wasn't clear enough? Very well, let me speak plainly. I...
Apologies, Kapitän... we're...
Captain to the Bridge! Morganas off the port!
How... Never mind. Let's go!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I...
Good grief! Gneisenau, we have to have boundaries.
You wish me to stay out of your quarters?
I wish you to stay out of my washroom!
And what do I get in exchange for this?
You...
Are you just now realizing you have nothing with which to threaten me? You can't kick me off, you can't demote me, you can't even ignore me. Therefore, I suggest a trade.
Much as I hate to admit this... Very well, what trade?
We discuss my rearming.

Fields.MenuText: Do I have a choice?
You've put me in a painful situation.
Discussion does not mean agreement. Very well.

Fields.DialogueText: No.
I apologize, but can't you at least admire my strong belief?
Discussion implies open–mindedness.
Very well. We'll continue this after I report to the bridge.
Thank you.
@BATTLE
And I quote, "In a meeting engagement in the fog, the side capable of developing a maximum firepower on contact will get the upper hand."
Who said that?
His name is Erwin Rommel. I suggest you remember that name.
Yes, yes, I recall. He wrote a book on infantry tactics, didn't he? Tell me, how many foot soldiers do you think we'll encounter here on the open seas?
Lessons of war are important regardless of the source. Just listen to his words.
And yet you wish to remove some of our guns?
Only to replace them with larger, more powerful ones. Maximum firepower, Kapitän.
With maximum danger, if we should miss.

Fields.MenuText: I fear you're not thinking through all of the risks.
Have you considered what fewer guns will mean to the crew's morale?
Do you think that we'll have the time in port to make these replacements?

Fields.DialogueText: And I fear you're not thinking through all the rewards.
Have you considered what bigger guns will do instead?
We make time for what's important, ja?
Radio traffic, Captain. Morganas incoming!
We'll continue this later.
@BATTLE
"One who cannot be victorious assumes a defensive posture; one who can be victorious attacks."
"In these circumstances by assuming a defensive posture, strength will be more than adequate, whereas in offensive actions it would be inadequate."
You know your Sun Tzu.
Only a poor strategist wouldn't.
Just because you know doesn't mean you understand. Did you listen to his words? By arguing for what you see as more strength, you argue for defense.
Which is what we're doing, Kapitän. We're not taking the fight to the Morganas so much as waiting for the fight to be brought to us.
I'd have to disagree with that. We take the battle to the Morganas every time we find them.
Precisely...when we find them. There is no capital for us to take, no government for us to capture. We must set ourselves in a defensive position so we can switch to offense upon success.

Fields.MenuText: Just this once, could you try making sense?
So we go defensive just to go offensive?
You know what's offensive? This conversation!

Fields.DialogueText: I am making perfect sense, Kapitän!
Thank you, yes!
Kapitän, I'm hurt!
I...excuse me, I need to shake this off.
Shake what off?
Battle stations, battle stations!
@BATTLE
It's the same way the Mongols beat the Chinese!
Several corrections. For starters, the Mongols did not beat the Chinese, they became Chinese. They had a turn at rule and were absorbed by the empire.
That's a bit revisionist of a view, don't you think?
Clearly not, since I stated it was true.
I can state that water is dry if you'd like, but simply stating it doesn't make it true.
I'm ignoring that. Secondly, the Mongols defeated the Chinese by uniting under a single leader instead of remaining fractured. Your point about firepower is irrelevant.
Is not! It's perfectly relevant to the issue at hand.
Which is?
I...you know, I actually forgot where I was going with this.

Fields.MenuText: Thank God, now we can move on to important matters!
Well, we can't move forward if we don't know where we're going.
I believe you were about to tell me how smart I am...

Fields.DialogueText: My needs aren't important?
We'd be fine if you'd let me steer, ja?
Quite the opposite, yes?
No.
It's a shame you feel that way, Kapitän. You know perfectly well what all this is directed towards.
Sadly, I do. You want your guns. I want my victories. Perhaps we can come to an arrangement.
You have an idea?
More a thought, really. We...
Captain, Morganas approaching!
But first, about that victory...
@BATTLE
We were speaking of my guns, Kapitän.
We were. I said I had a thought on the matter.
About how to get me my proper guns?
Let me level with you. Short of our being so damaged that we need to be placed in dry dock, I see no chance of you getting your desired upgrade.
Then why the charade? Why say you have some thoughts when you clearly don't?
I said I had some thoughts on the matter, and I do. In fact, I feel I should thank you for the initial push.
Me? What did I do?
It was your quote from Rommel about the fog. You see, one of the frequent problems we're having with targeting is the Nix fog, or the Morgana mists, however you like.
It gives them quite the advantage.
Indeed. However, it also puts them at somewhat of a disadvantage. For example, they rarely achieve surprise, surrounded as they are by this mist.
So their attempts to shroud themselves actually gives them away?

Fields.MenuText: As simple as it is true.
Thank you for stating the obvious.
Clearly you've given this some thought.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a bit simplistic...unless...sarcasm, Kapitän?
Don't blame me for...wait...sarcasm, Kapitän?
Delving into the realm of sarcasm again, Kapitän?
More like ill humor, Gneisenau. This enemy forces me to think in ways I've never thought before. Frankly, I've never had to...
Morganas off the starboard, Captain!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, you were saying something earlier about how you weren't used to thinking this way.
Yes, and is there any way to make you forget that little exchange?
But why? It was so honest and forthright.
Exactly, honest and forthright about a weakness. Weakness isn't a preferred ability in the Naval Protection Force's captains.
But knowing one's weakness and working to improve upon it is a sign of strength, wouldn't you agree?
I would, but my opinion alone isn't everything when it comes to keeping my command.
So what would you say is the most important thing in helping you keep it? Your command, that is.

Fields.MenuText: Victories, pure and simple.
Connections here and at home.
Willingness to obey.

Fields.DialogueText: Roma Victor, eh?
Not what you know but who, eh?
Hitler certainly appreciates that line of thinking.
Indeed.
That's understandable...but would you like to know what I think?
Can I stop you?
Ha, of course not! The only thing that...
Morganas, dead ahead.
Think of the devil and he appears. Come, let us see to our men.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I was hoping I could finish my thought.
Which one? Oh, about the most important quality in a captain?
That one. Leadership, Kapitän. Leadership.
Which boils down to winning, does it not?
Not entirely. Recall your lesson on Fabius Maximus and how his policy of not engaging Hannibal actually led to the Roman victory over the Carthaginians.
As I recall, it was actually Africanus who landed the decisive blow on Zama, was it not?
A blow he would have been unable to land had Hannibal not been so starved for battle on the boot.
So just what is it you're getting at, Gneisenau?
That leaders, true leaders, take the correct path and stick to it no matter who or what tries to drag them away.
Victories, propaganda, orders...everything pales in comparison to true leadership.

Fields.MenuText: And if a true leader needs to run?
And if leading means charging ahead against hopeless odds?
And if leading means laying down one's weapon at an enemy's feet?

Fields.DialogueText: Then a true leader will have the swiftest of feet.
Then a true leader will hold his sword high for all to see.
Then a true leader will keep his head high despite the cost.
An interesting view. I will have to think on it some more.
You see, thinking isn't as bad as you'd feared.
@BATTLE
(writing in journal) And so it was that I decided to place myself under the tutelage of Gneisenau, though for matters of military strategy only.
(continues writing in journal) Her first assignment was Caesar's commentaries on the Gallic War. I haven't read it for some time, but I can feel it coming back quickly.
Writing isn't reading, Kapitän.
I just needed to put down my thoughts, Gneisenau. It helps me keep them organized.
Anything in there about me?
Just how, um...
Yes?

Fields.MenuText: Annoying you can be.
Thoughtful you are.
Knowledgeable you are.

Fields.DialogueText: That's painful...but thanks, I think.
That's sweet. It's a lie, I think, but sweet.
Phh, I'm the most ignorant person on deck, I'd think.
You think? What I said doesn't, well, affect you in any way?
Kapitän, if I let everything anyone said on this ship get to me, I'd never get out of bed.
Bed?
You know what I mean. Don't be such a...
Morganas inbound, sir.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I have a favor to ask.
Truly? This should be interesting.
I doubt it. It's very mundane, really.
So mundane that you have to come and ask the captain instead of asking another crew member?
That's just it, actually. I was hoping you could help me get the men to study some of the things you are. You know, raise a crop of officers from this ship?

Fields.MenuText: Absolutely not. Let's focus on keeping the men in their place.
I must respectfully decline, but thank you for the thought.
Are you so eager to get rid of our men already?

Fields.DialogueText: In their place? But Kapitän, I...
It's more than just a thought, Kapitän! Won't you reconsider?
Get rid of... No, that's not what I... Kapitän, I...
No, I will remain completely firm on this one, Gneisenau. The men need to remain focused on their duties.
Kapitän, I...
They need to follow orders, Gneisenau! Our men don't need to think like a general to load a gun or repair a deck, they need to let their bodies do the work and keep the mind clear, understood?
Understood. Permission to withdraw.
Granted.
@BATTLE
Gneisenau, are you around?
I'm always around, Kapitän.
Good, I'd like your opinion on these duty changes.
Why ask me, Kapitän? Can't you make your own decisions?
All right, why the cold shoulder?
Cold shoulder? I control my temperature perfectly, why would one shoulder be any colder than the other?
I... It's an expression. It means you're being distant.
Distant? No, just proper. I don't believe you want my assistance in decision making. You made that quite clear, really.
Is this about not wanting to make the men read strategy books? Gneisenau, do you even remotely understand why I need to keep the men away from those things?
I assume it's because you want to keep them in their 'proper place'?

Fields.MenuText: How... You don't know me at all!
How... I find your assessment disturbing.
How... That's fairly cynical even for you.

Fields.DialogueText: I know you well enough to understand you don't want the men thinking for themselves.
You know what disturbs me? Knowing you don't want the men thinking for themselves.
What else was I to think? You don't want the men thinking for themselves.
No, I told you I needed to let their bodies do the thinking for them. We're deep into fighting a foe we can't even begin to understand.
The last thing I need is the men questioning my orders.
You think they would do that just because they read Caesar?
Among other things, yes. Consider this...
Battle stations, battle stations!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I feel I owe you an apology.
I'm sure you owe me several. For which thing are you apologizing for now?
A joke, Kapitän?
Mostly. Continue.
I owe you an apology for thinking you wished to keep your men down instead of lifting them up. I understand something better of your thinking now.
I see. What illuminated your thoughts, if I may ask?
The last few encounters have been rather intense. When I had the chance to observe, I noted the men's efficiency, how they worked their weapons and moved to their stations.
And that has what to do with reading Caesar? I understand, mind you; I just want to hear your opinion.
Nothing in itself, but by encouraging the men at the improper time to climb from their station to something higher...

Fields.MenuText: We'd end up on a ship full of captains and no one to run the guns?
We'd turn this ship from one of elite sailors into a floating trial by fire?
The men turn to fighting over promotions instead of the Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Just so, Kapitän, hence the apology.
A frightening thought, indeed. That's why I felt the apology necessary.
Something I didn't see at first, true, which is why I apologized.
Noted and accepted. Now, about that list?
I'll take a look at it and give you my opinion...
Morganas!
...after we knock these idiots back.
@BATTLE
How was the reading, Kapitän?
Well enough. Caesar won in the end, just like he always does.
Did he now? Interesting.
What, you don't think he was victorious against the Gauls?
In the short term, one could certainly suppose that. In the long term, well, just ask yourself if the empire still exists.
I would assume you would think it in Berlin, now.
Ironic, isn't it, how the Empire moved to the place where its most famous son made his name through conquest?
Ironic, indeed.
All thanks to the Führer, I suppose.
Sir, we've spotted Morganas headed our direction!
Ready, Gneisenau?
Always.
@BATTLE
No rest for the weary then?
None. You have your assignment, I suggest you get to it.
But why "The Art of War"? Don't you remember me quoting it to you? I'd say that shows my knowledge there.
Despite the dust of centuries, Sun Tzu still speaks a wealth of intelligence. Quoting and knowing are two different things, and as the master said, know your enemy.
But how can we? The Morganas give us little to study, and what we do get is...
Battle stations, Morganas sighted.
@BATTLE
You were saying, Kapitän?
Only that it is impossible to know our enemy.
Permission to speak plainly, Kapitän.
Granted.
You yourself once said that weakness wasn't a strength, and yet you have embraced yours and are eliminating it on a daily basis.

Fields.MenuText: Ugh, hurry it up already.
Go on, but tread carefully.
Are you going somewhere with this?

Fields.DialogueText: You can't hurry perfection, Kapitän.
Don't I always? I mean, this is something I...
Aren't I always?
Find the point, Gneisenau, and quickly.
My point is that your weakness was your enemy. You now know it and therefore how to crush it. The more you strengthen this point, the stronger your whole becomes.
I have to admit that I'm scared, Gneisenau.
Of bettering yourself?
Hardly. I'm scared because I think I actually understood that logic. Very well, I'll work on Sun Tzu once everything else is complete. Dismissed.
Kapitän, if I may be so bold as to ask, who was that?
Hmm? Oh, that was an old friend from my academy days. He heard we would be close by and decided to come over for a glass of port.
Interesting. Kapitän, did you happen to note why he was in the area?
I don't understand.
His ship, Kapitän. It isn't a courier ship, nor is it assigned to our task force, so why would he be in the area?

Fields.MenuText: Just what are you getting at?
Do you know how paranoid you sound?
It wasn't my place to ask, so I didn't.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure. It's just... Something didn't seem right about your conversation.
I know I sound strange, but so did your conversation.
You don't think his questions were a bit odd?
You were listening in on us?
You know I hear everything that goes on in the ship, Kapitän. His questions about our recent successes were a bit pointed, almost sharp.
Gneisenau, I...
Battle stations, battle stations!
@BATTLE
You know, I found a quote from Frederick the Second that I thought you would find interesting.
Reading ahead? Naughty, naughty, Kapitän.
I'm ignoring that. The quote was this...
"...not one of them would remain in the army." Yes, perfectly timed.
And yet you were arguing for the education of my men. Can you explain?
The soldiers in Frederick's age were treated much differently from ours. If our men began to think, they'd certainly leave, but only to greater things.

Fields.MenuText: Because serving under me isn't great enough?
Only if they didn't die in battle first.
Well, we certainly can't have them being great then, can we?

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, you misunderstand me!
How pessimistic you are, Kapitän.
Ah... Kapitän...you can't think that I...
No, Gneisenau... I only pull on your anchor chain.
You're kidding with me?
Much like a good steak, it happens...rarely.
@BATTLE
Gneisenau, a word please?
Of course, Kapitän. I'm in such a good mood, I might even let you have two.
Ha, ha.
That's two.
Do you remember the old friend of mine from the academy who visited, the one you weren't terribly fond of?
I recall, yes. I believe suspicious would be the more accurate term.
Turns out you were right to be concerned. I just received a telegraph from Command outlining several 'concerns' they have heard.
Concerns?
Careful, Gneisenau. Keep that temper in check until you hear what I have to say.
Is there anything you can say that will give me reason for calm?

Fields.MenuText: No, but I'm ordering you to be calm anyway.
No, but I can't have you stomping around the ship like that.
No, but... Actually, just no.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll have you know that...
Stomping around? If I were stomping, you'd know it, you...
That's what I thought! If Command thinks that they can...
Captain to the bridge! Morganas off the port side!
Argh, these insufferable interruptions!
@BATTLE
So tell me what your so–called friend did to you.
I'm still not sure it was him...not totally, at least.
Assume that it was. Tell me about the telegraph.
In short, it insinuated that I was speaking about grand strategies where my station should be winning the battles to which I am assigned.
That...actually doesn't sound so bad.
The wording was a bit different, mind you. It was made clear that the strategic thinking on the level of Caesar and Frederick would not be needed from a captain in my position.
There is no small thinking, only small battles...and small men.

Fields.MenuText: Refrain yourself, Gneisenau; these are still our superiors.
I feel the same, but we must take care; these are still our superiors.
Men who can order me removed and hung for treason; they are, after all, our superiors.

Fields.DialogueText: Superior in rank only, Kapitän, not intelligence. That much is obvious.
Superior in inferior thinking, you mean.
Superiors such as they have been dealt with before in much more...permanent...ways.
Too far, Gneisenau, too far.
My apologies, Kapitän. I spoke in haste.
You spoke in anger. What would Fabius have said to that?
Ahh, there's my strategic thinking. Now, before I get myself into more trouble, permission to leave?
Granted.
@BATTLE
...And that is how Napoleon used his place in the center to win Italy for France.
In some ways, it's the same as Nelson did at Trafalgar. By splitting his forces and punching through the center, he paralyzed part of Villeneuve's forces.
That's somewhat true, but on a bit of a different scope. A more appropriate analogy might be the battle of Tsushima.
Not remotely! Trafalgar shows all the hallmarks of taking the center and using it to...
Captain to the bridge.
That's odd.
What is?
I'm hearing that...hold on...it sounds like we're being asked to move in for support. Seems another ship is deep in trouble and sailing blind.

Fields.MenuText: You know, it still unnerves me how you can do that.
Times like these, I'm glad you can hear what's going on in the ship.
Remind me never to sing in my washroom again.

Fields.DialogueText: And yet you don't turn it down.
And then there was that time in the washroom...
Your singing at the sink isn't bad, it's in the...
Yes, well, let's move along.
Noted. To the Bridge?
After you.
@BATTLE
(writing in journal) I find myself questioning the persecution not of the war itself, but of the Morgana problem.
(continues writing) The ability of the Morganas to produce fog is fascinating and troubling at the same time for reasons already spelled out, but the manner in which it is produced is questionable.
(continues writing) If we are to know our enemy, we must know how these things are done so that we may undo them and remove the enemy's advantage.
I see you're doing more organizing of thoughts, Kapitän.
Hmm, I thought I heard you come in.
Ah, and I thought I had been so sneaky.
There's a strange sort of popping sound when you materialize, almost like you're pushing out the air in your way.
That's quite observant of you, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Well, you did say to know your enemy, didn't you?
Glad to see you think so highly of me.
A compliment? From you? Are you quite well?

Fields.DialogueText: Enemy, am I? I'll show you an enemy!
Kapitän, I...
I've given you plenty of compliments, haven't I?
At ease, Gneisenau. Again, like the good steak...
...your jokes are best presented rare. Still, joking aside, you've made remarkable progress given the constraints of battle. Speaking of which...yes, here it comes.
Battle stations, battle stations!
@BATTLE
...So if we swing over this way...
...And shift our fire here, here, aaaand over here...
...We would not only increase the likelihood of scoring hits, but also give the impression of more ships in the task force.
Precisely! Tell me, what made you think of this?
Rossbach of all things.
Really? How did Frederick's move at Rossbach make you think of this? I don't see any resemblance at all.

Fields.MenuText: It just...came to me.
Your shortcoming isn't my problem.
It all seems so simple.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, whatever it was you did when it happened, do it again!
Kapitän, perhaps it is best I consider your jokes are no longer rare.
Simple for you, perhaps. I'm proud.
And it appears we may have a chance to test that out right now!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I have another book for you. Kapitän, are you well?
Well enough, I suppose, but please, no new book right now.
All right, I...are you certain you are well? What's that paper?
Orders. I'm to submit for a review at a time of Command's choosing. This is simply a courtesy notification, not a request.
Review? Why, of what?
Of my recent conduct. Our successes have Command wondering if perhaps we...
We what...

Fields.MenuText: If we aren't perhaps colluding with the enemy.
If we aren't perhaps more lucky than we are good.
If we aren't perhaps inflating our successes.

Fields.DialogueText: That's absurd! Tell them to ask anyone on this ship, they'll see!
They think luck is what's kept us alive out here? Tell them to ask the crew if we're just lucky!
And the rescues we've performed, are those 'inflated' as well? Just ask our crew, then!
They will, actually. We're to expect a team of inspectors at any time between now and, well, whenever this war ends.
This is an outrage, a disgrace, a...
All hands report to battle stations, all hands report to battle...
@BATTLE
Any word on this team, yet?
None, nor will there be until they set foot on this deck.
Do you think they will? I mean, do you think they'll brave the battles we've been through?
Doubtless they will. My concern is will they see what is real, or will they see what they wish?
And what is it you think they wish to see? Shouldn't they celebrate our victories?
One would think. I'm sure Command knows what they're doing.
But will the inspection team?

Fields.MenuText: Of course they will; our men are the best in the world, after all.
Of course they will; incompetence doesn't last long in Command.
Of course they will; our luck wouldn't let them be fools.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we will hope for the best.
Greatness rises, incompetence sinks? Very well, we shall see.
No, we'll get the sharpest officer looking for promotion. I don't like this.
I trust...all will be well.
@BATTLE
It seems we've gained a bit of a reprieve, Gneisenau.
Oh? Tell me.
Don't feign ignorance. The officer of the watch told me you were there when word came.
About the delay in the inspection team? Yes, I heard. I just wanted you to be able to pass on good news for once.
That's kind of you.
Does this mean you can resume your studies?

Fields.MenuText: I'm just now out of the fire and you want to put me back in?
Perhaps this isn't the best time to think on that.
I... I don't think I'm ready for that just yet.

Fields.DialogueText: The best blades aren't tempered just once, Kapitän.
The best time is when you are thinking about it, Kapitän.
But Kapitän, surely you understand...
I understand, Gneisenau, but for now...I need to think on my options.
@BATTLE
Argh, just write it down already!
Not until you stop staring over my shoulder.
The suspense is killing me, truly it is.
And the sooner you back away...
Fine, fine. There, you have your precious space, are you happy?
(writing in journal) And so I have decided that yes, I will continue to study tactics and strategy under the auspices of my ship's Belle.
I knew it, I knew it!
(continues writing) Come what may, as hard as it might be, I think that our studies have made me a better captain.
And a better person.
I'm sorry, what?
Kapitän, I... This is something I've been thinking on for a while and... Well... I just wanted you to know how much I admire you.
You're becoming quite the leader. I'm proud of you.

Fields.MenuText: It's good to hear you say that, Gneisenau. I'll always value your friendship.
It's good to hear you say that, Gneisenau. Your...approval means a lot to me.

Fields.DialogueText: And what excellent friends we can be, Kapitän.
And I desire yours as well.
